title: The Blueprint Chamber
story: You enter the grand Castle of Classes. The royal architect greets you: "Welcome! Here we learn to create BLUEPRINTS for objects. Create a class called 'Hero' with two public properties: 'Name' (string) and 'Health' (int)."
solution: class Hero { public string Name { get; set; } public int Health { get; set; } }
hints: Properties use: public type Name { get; set; }
class Hero { public string Name { get; set; } public int Health { get; set; } }

steps.explanation:
A CLASS is like a blueprint or template. Just like an architect's blueprint describes how to build a house, a class describes how to create an object.

You define a class ONCE, then create many objects from it!
steps.tip: Think: Class = Cookie Cutter, Object = Cookie. One cutter, many cookies!
Good class names: Hero, Player, Enemy, Weapon. Bad names: DoStuff, MyClass, x.
{ get; set; } is shorthand for 'this property can be read and written'. We'll learn more later!

steps.codeExample:
Hero hero = new Hero();  // Create a new Hero
hero.Name = "Aria";      // Set the Name property
hero.Health = 100;       // Set the Health property
steps.tip: The 'new' keyword calls the class's constructor and creates a fresh object in memory.

steps.explanation:
Access properties using DOT NOTATION:

object.PropertyName

You can read from or write to properties this way.
steps.codeExample:
hero.Name = "Aria";           // Write to property
string heroName = hero.Name;  // Read from property

Console.WriteLine(hero.Name); // Prints: Aria
steps.tip: The dot (.) means 'look inside this object and access this member'.

exploration.introduction: Classes are blueprints for creating objects. Let's explore how they work!

examples.title: A Simple Class
examples.explanation:
Here's a basic class with two properties. We create an object from it and set its properties.

Notice: the class is the template, the object is the actual thing!

examples.title: Multiple Objects from One Class
examples.explanation:
One class can create MANY objects. Each object has its own separate data.

Changing one hero doesn't affect the others!

examples.title: Different Property Types
examples.explanation:
Properties can be any type: string, int, bool, double, or even other classes!

Here's a more complex example.

examples.title: Your Turn!
examples.explanation:
Create a Hero class with:
- Name (string)
- Health (int)

Then create a hero, set Name to "Aria" and Health to 100.
